title: Sulayman Khalid COMPLAINS about Goulburn's supermax conditions as 'onerous'
text:
A convicted terrorist who planned attacks at a jail and on an Australian Federal Police building has complained his prison sentence is 'very onerous'.

Sulayman Khalid was sentenced to 22 years in prison after he pleaded guilty in 2017 to conspiring to commit a terror attack in 2014.

On Friday he faced the New South Wales Court of Criminal Appeal to make a case for re-sentencing, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.

He claimed his youth and minor record weren't taken into account during sentencing.

Sulayman Khalid was sentenced to 22 years in prison after he pleaded guilty in 2017 to conspiring to commit a terror attack in 2014

Khalid is currently housed in Goulburn's supermax prison, where he is considered a Category AA inmate.

Category AA inmates are male inmates who are believed to represent a risk to national security.

The court heard Khalid is confined to a '2m x 3m' cell with 'a cage at the back of the cell', which is about 2m by 2m.

His barrister John Stratton SC said this, paired with the fact he only is allowed outside an hour a day, is 'very onerous'.

'The conditions of imprisonment are very onerous ... [with] no suggestion of any change ... in the immediate future,' said Mr Stratton SC.

He asked the three judges to give weight to the matters that Justice Geoffrey Bellew 'did not give sufficient regard' to in the original sentencing.

Mr Stratton told the court that Khalid's lack of criminal record at the time of sentencing and his minimal breaches since being in prison should be taken into account.

Khalid's solicitor Stephen Alexander said in an affidavit filed to the court that his client was unable to access educational resources despite his expressed interest to.

In 2017 when Justice Bellew sentenced Khalid he said: 'He was a devout terrorist ... corrupted by a dangerous, violent and perverted ideology to which he unequivocally subscribed, which he wore as a badge of honour, but which has no place in any civilised society'

David Jordan, who represented The Crown, said while Khalid never committed the offences there was 'not a lot of difference' between his case and Raban Alou, who was sentenced to 33 years for his role in the death of Curtis Cheng.

He said that Khalid also was in a position of leadership among the conspirators.

In 2017 when Justice Bellew sentenced Khalid he said: 'He was a devout terrorist ... corrupted by a dangerous, violent and perverted ideology to which he unequivocally subscribed, which he wore as a badge of honour, but which has no place in any civilised society'.

One of the three judges hearing the appeal - Justice Harrison - said it was 'a bit hard to get away from the fact the conditions of incarceration are fairly harsh'.

The NSW Court of Criminal Appeal has reserved its decision in the matter.
description: Sulayman Khalid was sentenced to 22 years in prison after he pleaded guilty in 2017 to conspiring to commit a terror attack in 2014. He faced the NSW Court of Criminal Appeals on Friday.
authors: Claudia Poposki For Daily Mail Australia
